3. Warum ist index.html sinnvoll oder nÃ¶tig?

Ohne index.html:

Die erste gefundene Datei aus dieser Liste wird verwendet, wenn kein genauer Dateiname in der URL angegeben ist.

Wenn du professionelle Webentwicklung machst, ist es best practice, mit index.html oder index.php zu arbeiten â€“ oder den Server bewusst anders zu konfigurieren.

Ich habe dir eine kompakte HTML-Grundstruktur mit doppelt geschweiften Platzhaltern ({{ â€¦ }}) erstellt. Sie orientiert sich am Inhalt deiner hochgeladenen Elementor-Vorlage, ist aber bewusst als statischer OnePager angelegt, damit du sie spÃ¤ter per Skript, Static-Site-Generator oder Template-Engine ganz einfach befÃ¼llen kannst.

Die Datei heiÃŸt landing-template.html und liegt in der Canvas-Seitenleiste â€“ dort kannst du sie direkt bearbeiten, kopieren oder herunterladen.

Was als NÃ¤chstes?

Schritt 2 â€“ Inhalte automatisch aus einer Kunden-URL extrahieren

Ziel: Du gibst einmal die URL der bestehenden Kunden-Seite ein â†’ erhÃ¤ltst eine sauber strukturierte JSON-Datei, deren Keys exakt zu den Platzhaltern im Template passen ({{headline}}, {{image_hero}} usw.).
Die JSON landet z. B. in /data/kunde123.json und kann anschlieÃŸend ohne Handarbeit in Schritt 3 in dein landing-template.html gerendert werden.

1 | Minimal-Setup

bash

2 | Platzhalter-Mapping festlegen

python
PLACEHOLDERS = {
    "meta_title":       lambda soup: soup.title.string.strip() if soup.title else "",
    "meta_description": lambda soup: soup.find("meta", attrs={"name": "description"})["content"].strip()
                          if soup.find("meta", attrs={"name": "description"}) else "",
    "headline":         lambda soup: soup.find("h1").get_text(strip=True) if soup.find("h1") else "",
    "subheadline":      lambda soup: soup.find("h2").get_text(strip=True) if soup.find("h2") else "",
    "intro_text":       lambda soup: soup.find("p").get_text(strip=True)   if soup.find("p") else "",
    # Beispiel fÃ¼r Benefits â€“ nimm die ersten drei <h3>/<p>-Paare
    "benefit_title_1":  lambda soup: nth_text(soup, "h3", 0),
    "benefit_text_1":   lambda soup: nth_text(soup, "p", 1),
    "benefit_title_2":  lambda soup: nth_text(soup, "h3", 1),
    "benefit_text_2":   lambda soup: nth_text(soup, "p", 2),
    "benefit_title_3":  lambda soup: nth_text(soup, "h3", 2),
    "benefit_text_3":   lambda soup: nth_text(soup, "p", 3),
}

Tipp: Das Mapping gleich am Anfang sauber definieren â€“ dann musst du spÃ¤ter nur noch die Lambdas anpassen, wenn deine Platzhalter-Namen oder die Kunden-HTML-Struktur variieren.

3 | Beispiel-Skript extract_to_json.py

python
import json, os, re, requests
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
from slugify import slugify
from readability import Document
from PIL import Image
from io import BytesIO
from urllib.parse import urljoin, urlparse

### ---------- Hilfsfunktionen ----------

def nth_text(soup, tag, n):
    el = soup.find_all(tag)
    return el[n].get_text(strip=True) if len(el) > n else ""

def download_img(img_tag, base_url, out_dir="images"):
    src = img_tag.get("src") or img_tag.get("data-src")
    if not src: return ""
    img_url = urljoin(base_url, src)
    resp = requests.get(img_url, timeout=10)
    resp.raise_for_status()
    # Dateiname aus URL oder alt-Text erzeugen
    ext = os.path.splitext(urlparse(img_url).path)[1] or ".jpg"
    fname = slugify(img_tag.get("alt", "image")) + ext
    os.makedirs(out_dir, exist_ok=True)
    # Komprimieren (optional â†’ Pillow)
    img = Image.open(BytesIO(resp.content))
    img.save(os.path.join(out_dir, fname), optimize=True, quality=80)
    return f"{out_dir}/{fname}"

### ---------- Hauptlogik ----------

def extract(url):
    html = requests.get(url, timeout=15).text
    # readability: Hauptcontent isolieren, erspart MÃ¼ll
    article_html = Document(html).summary(html_partial=True)
    soup = BeautifulSoup(article_html, "html.parser")
    
    data = {}
    for key, extractor in PLACEHOLDERS.items():
        try:
            data[key] = extractor(soup)
        except Exception:
            data[key] = ""
    # Beispiel: Hero-Bild = erstes <img> im Dokument
    first_img = soup.find("img")
    data["image_hero"] = download_img(first_img, url) if first_img else ""
    return data

def save_json(data, slug):
    os.makedirs("data", exist_ok=True)
    with open(f"data/{slug}.json", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
        json.dump(data, f, ensure_ascii=False, indent=2)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import sys
    if len(sys.argv) != 2:
        print("Aufruf: python extract_to_json.py <URL>")
        sys.exit(1)
    url = sys.argv[1]
    slug = slugify(urlparse(url).netloc)
    dataset = extract(url)
    save_json(dataset, slug)
    print(f"âœ“ extrahiert â†’ data/{slug}.json")

  • So merkst du sofort, ob du bei dieser URL noch manuell nachbessern musst.

  • Ab hier ist es nur noch ein Template-Render-Lauf (Schritt 3) + Deployment â†’ Link an Kunde.

Kurzantwort

Ja. GitHub Pages kann jede statische Website, die du aus deinem Template + JSON generierst, live ausliefern. Du hast zwei gÃ¤ngige Wege:

WegVorteilNachteil

3 | GitHub Actions-Workflow deploy.yml

yaml
name: Build & Deploy Landingpage

on:
  push:
    branches: [ main ]          # jedes Mal, wenn main gepusht wird
  workflow_dispatch:            # manueller Trigger mÃ¶glich

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Use Node 20
        uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: '20'

      - run: npm ci              # installiert genau die gelockten Pakete
      - run: npm run build       # erstellt _site/

      - name: Deploy to gh-pages
        uses: peaceiris/actions-gh-pages@v4
        with:
          github_token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
          publish_dir: _site     # dieser Ordner wird hochgeladen

1 | Python-Code builder.py

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
"""
Builder: scrape a website, extract basic content,
fill an HTML template, copy hero & logo, write docs/<slug>/index.html
Usage:  python builder.py https://example.com my-slug
"""
import os, re, sys, json, requests, shutil, mimetypes
from pathlib import Path
from urllib.parse import urljoin, urlparse
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
from slugify import slugify
from jinja2 import Environment, FileSystemLoader

# ------------------- CONFIG -------------------
PLACEHOLDERS = {
    "meta_title":       lambda s: s.title.string.strip() if s.title else "",
    "meta_description": lambda s: (s.find("meta", {"name": "description"}) or {}).get("content",""),
    "headline":         lambda s: (s.find("h1") or {}).get_text(strip=True),
    "subheadline":      lambda s: (s.find("h2") or {}).get_text(strip=True),
    "intro_text":       lambda s: (s.find("p")  or {}).get_text(strip=True)
}
OUTPUT_DIR = Path("docs")
TEMPLATE_DIR = Path("template")
TEMPLATE_NAME = "landing-template.html"
# ------------------------------------------------

def download_first_img(soup, base_url, name):
    img = soup.find("img")
    if not img or not img.get("src"):
        return ""
    src = urljoin(base_url, img["src"])
    data = requests.get(src, timeout=10).content
    ext  = mimetypes.guess_extension(requests.head(src, timeout=10).headers.get("content-type","image/jpeg"))
    fname = f"{name}{ext or '.jpg'}"
    out = OUTPUT_DIR / name / "assets"
    out.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)
    with open(out / fname, "wb") as f: f.write(data)
    return f"assets/{fname}"

def scrape(url, slug):
    html = requests.get(url, timeout=15).text
    soup = BeautifulSoup(html, "html.parser")
    data = {k:extractor(soup) for k,extractor in PLACEHOLDERS.items()}

    # Bilder
    data["hero_image_url"] = download_first_img(soup, url, "hero")
    data["logo_image_url"] = download_first_img(soup, url, "logo")

    # Render
    env = Environment(loader=FileSystemLoader(TEMPLATE_DIR))
    tpl = env.get_template(TEMPLATE_NAME)
    rendered = tpl.render(**data)

    out_dir = OUTPUT_DIR / slug
    out_dir.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)
    (out_dir / "index.html").write_text(rendered, encoding="utf-8")

def main():
    if len(sys.argv) != 3:
        print("Usage: builder.py <url> <slug>")
        sys.exit(1)
    scrape(sys.argv[1], slugify(sys.argv[2]))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

requirements.txt

nginx

2 | GitHub-Actions-Workflow .github/workflows/deploy.yml

yaml
name: Build & Deploy

on:
  push:
    branches: [main]

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Setup Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v5
        with:
          python-version: '3.12'

      - run: pip install -r requirements.txt

      # Option A: mehrere URLs aus urls.csv verarbeiten
      - name: Loop through urls.csv
        run: |
          while IFS=',' read url slug; do
            python builder.py "$url" "$slug"
          done < urls.csv

      - name: Deploy docs/ to GitHub Pages
        uses: peaceiris/actions-gh-pages@v4
        with:
          github_token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
          publish_dir: docs

Jede Zeile in urls.csv hat das Format

arduino
https://www.peter-albert.com,peter-albert
https://zweiter-kunde.de,zweiter-kunde

Was passiert intern?

  1. builder.py holt sich HTML, extrahiert Kerntexte, lÃ¤dt nur das erste Bild (Hero) + Logo.

  2. FÃ¼gt alles in dein HTML-Template ein (Jinja2), schreibt docs/<slug>/index.html + Bilder in docs/<slug>/assets/.

Warum diese LÃ¶sung reicht

  • Keine lokale Arbeit mehr: Du Ã¤nderst nur noch urls.csv oder Template, pushst â€“ fertig.

  • Skalierbar: 100 Kunden? GitHub Actions scrapet & baut sie in einem Lauf.

  • Kosten = 0 â‚¬: GitHub Pages hostet statische Sites gratis, SSL inklusive.

  • Portierbar: Du kannst das Gleiche auch bei Netlify oder Vercel verwenden, wenn du willst (nur Publish-Step anpassen).

Wenn du noch â€¦

  • buildCommand lÃ¤uft in der Build-VM:

<details> <summary><strong>builder.py</strong> (kopieren & einfÃ¼gen)</summary> 
python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
import os, sys, mimetypes, requests
from pathlib import Path
from urllib.parse import urljoin, urlparse
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
from slugify import slugify
from jinja2 import Environment, FileSystemLoader

# ---------------- config ----------------
PLACEHOLDERS = {
    "meta_title":       lambda s: s.title.string.strip() if s.title else "",
    "meta_description": lambda s: (s.find("meta", {"name": "description"}) or {}).get("content", ""),
    "headline":         lambda s: (s.find("h1") or {}).get_text(strip=True),
    "subheadline":      lambda s: (s.find("h2") or {}).get_text(strip=True),
    "intro_text":       lambda s: (s.find("p")  or {}).get_text(strip=True),
}
TEMPLATE_DIR = Path("template")
OUTPUT_DIR   = Path("docs")
# ----------------------------------------

def dl_first_img(soup, base, name, out):
    img = soup.find("img")
    if not img or not img.get("src"): return ""
    src   = urljoin(base, img["src"])
    data  = requests.get(src, timeout=10).content
    ext   = mimetypes.guess_extension(requests.head(src,timeout=10).headers.get("content-type","image/jpeg")) or ".jpg"
    fname = f"{name}{ext}"
    (out/"assets").mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)
    (out/"assets"/fname).write_bytes(data)
    return f"assets/{fname}"

def build(url, slug):
    html = requests.get(url, timeout=15).text
    soup = BeautifulSoup(html, "html.parser")
    data = {k:f(soup) for k,f in PLACEHOLDERS.items()}

    out = OUTPUT_DIR/slug
    data["hero_image_url"] = dl_first_img(soup, url, "hero", out)
    data["logo_image_url"] = dl_first_img(soup, url, "logo", out)

    env = Environment(loader=FileSystemLoader(TEMPLATE_DIR))
    rendered = env.get_template("landing-template.html").render(**data)
    out.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)
    (out/"index.html").write_text(rendered, encoding="utf-8")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    if len(sys.argv)!=3:
        sys.exit("Usage: builder.py <url> <slug>")
    build(sys.argv[1], slugify(sys.argv[2]))

    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Setup Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v5
        with:
          python-version: '3.12'

      - run: pip install -r requirements.txt

      - name: Scrape & generate for every line in urls.csv
        run: |
          while IFS=',' read url slug; do
            python builder.py "$url" "$slug"
          done < urls.csv

      - name: Setup Node
        uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: '20'

      - run: npm ci
      - run: npm run build      # passt Template an, falls du Eleventy nutzt

      - name: Deploy to gh-pages
        uses: peaceiris/actions-gh-pages@v4
        with:
          publish_dir: docs
          github_token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
</details>
